bestBHT.bht: The apostles obeyed Christ's instructions by shaking off the dust of their feet against the people of Iconium. This symbolic act marked their refusal to have further contact, demonstrating their reverence for the gospel and their aversion to the wicked. Iconium's significance as a populous city positioned on major Roman roads and its role in the formation of the Turkish empire added weight to this gesture. By shaking off the dust, the apostles conveyed that the very soil of the city was considered defiling, cutting off any further interaction.

bhtAttempts.bht: The apostles, following Christ's instructions, symbolically shook off the dust of their feet against the people of Iconium, a city known for its role in the consolidation of the Turkish empire and for its position as a meeting place of Roman roads. This gesture, akin to removing one's sandal and shaking out the dust, served as a dramatic statement to cut off further intercourse. It conveyed that the city was regarded as profane and defiling. Thus, the severity of this action demonstrates the apostles' reverence for the gospel and their commitment to avoiding fellowship with the wicked.

The apostles, following Christ's instructions, shook off the dust of their feet against the people of Iconium, a city contributing to the Turkish empire and located on the highway from east to west. This dramatic gesture symbolized the apostles' refusal to have any further interaction with them, effectively cutting off fellowship. It demonstrated their reverence for the gospel and their desire to avoid contamination from the wicked. By shaking off the dust, they conveyed the profane and defiling nature of the city.

The apostles, in accordance with Christ's guidance, shook off the dust of their feet against the people of Iconium. This symbolic action was a dramatic gesture that signified the defiling nature of the city and prohibited any further interaction. Iconium, situated on the Roman roads and instrumental in the Turkish empire's consolidation, embodied a profane environment. This act of shaking off the dust demonstrated the apostles' reverence for the gospel and their determination to avoid association with the wicked.

The apostles obeyed Christ's instructions by shaking off the dust of their feet against the people of Iconium. This symbolic act marked their refusal to have further contact, demonstrating their reverence for the gospel and their aversion to the wicked. Iconium's significance as a populous city positioned on major Roman roads and its role in the formation of the Turkish empire added weight to this gesture. By shaking off the dust, the apostles conveyed that the very soil of the city was considered defiling, cutting off any further interaction.

The apostles, following Christ's instructions, shook off the dust of their feet against the people of Iconium. This dramatic gesture, a symbolic token of defilement, forbade further intercourse and conveyed the apostles' aversion to fellowship with the wicked. Iconium, situated on major Roman roads and contributing to the Turkish empire, possessed significance as a populous city. By shaking off the dust, the apostles demonstrated their reverence for the gospel and their resolve to distance themselves from the profane nature of the city.
